items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Pursuant to Article XIII-B of the State Constitution and Government Code Section 7900 et seq., all community college districts are required to compute an annual appropriation limit.  The appropriation regulation limits the growth in community college district spending to be no faster than the growth in population and inflation.  The appropriation limit is adjusted annually for changes in the price index, population, and other applicable factors.
	 
The District's 2014-15 appropriation limit was $222,365,328.  The District's 2015-16 appropriation limit has been determined to be $232,198,670.
	 
Submitted by:
 Kevin McElroy, Vice Chancellor, Business Services, x6202
Additional contact names:
 Hector Quinonez, Executive Director, Fiscal Services, x6250
Is backup provided?
 Yes
items.item_recommendation: Staff recommend that the Board adopt the attached resolution establishing the 2015-16 appropriation limit at $232,198,670.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On February 2, 2009, the board authorized a contract with Abtech Support to provide Colocation Site Disaster Recovery Services for three (3) years. The contract provides hosting space in an off-site location to house back-up servers and data equipment, and also provides three (3) years of high speed connectivity network service between the district data center and collocation site at Carlsbad, CA. The recurring costs include Abtech maintenance services and network connectivity charges to the CENIC network.
	 
CENIC is a non-profit 501(c)3 formed and managed by the educational segments which includes the University of California, the California State Universities, the California Community Colleges, the majority of the K-12 school districts, plus Stanford, Caltech and USC. CENIC’s primary mission is to provide affordable, high-speed network connections for the K-20 Research & Education community in California. Because Abtech Support is not eligible for a direct connection of CENIC’s CalREN network, CENIC cannot invoice Abtech Support directly and thus needs to contract with and invoice district directly. At the April 6, 2009 Board meeting, the Board approved CENIC as a separate vendor for this purpose.
	 
Based on the board approved agenda item, ETS entered an agreement with CENIC and established a contract agreement to execute the payment to CENIC. The contract has since been renewed for a 3 year term on June18, 2012 by the Board. The renewed contract is due to expire at end of June 30, 2015.
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih
Is backup provided?
Yes
items.item_recommendation: ETS requests board approval to enter agreement with CENIC for another 3 years with a total amount not to exceed $78,566.40 including applicable taxes and telecommunication surcharges. The new contract will run from July 1, 2015 to June 30, 2018.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Foothill College has been awarded $300,000 in funding from the California Community College's Chancellor's Office Division of Workforce and Economic Development for a one-year renewal (July 1, 2015 - June 30, 2016) grant for Catherine Ayers to continue her project management work as a Deputy Sector Navigator working with the Energy Efficiency industry and Utilities sector in the Bay Area. This grant is in support of the Doing What Matters for Jobs and the Economy framework to enhance collaborative regional work on curricular pathways in sectors important to regional economies. The grant project has been one of a number of Bay Area projects that has supported the creation of a network of Deputy Sector Navigators. This project continues to build upon Foothill-De Anza earlier work, including the SolarTech Workforce Innovations Collaborative (SWIC) project, in the Energy sector and the successful collaborations with City College of San Francisco, Skyline College and industry partners that distinguished  the first year of the grant 2013 -14.
	 
Catherine Ayers was named Deputy Sector Navigator on this award as detailed in the attached Independent Contractor Agreement dated May 11, 2015 because of her experience with the energy efficiency industry and her knowledge of workforce development in the community colleges. As required by the Chancellor's Office, the Deputy Sector Navigator is an 80% to full-time role, working with colleges, industry partners and other stakeholders for this sector in the Bay Area.
	 
The Independent Contractor Agreement was authorized  by Foothill College Vice President of Workforce Development and Institutional Advancement John Mummert for $141,450 for contracted services and $4,500 for expenses, for a total cost not to exceed $145,950.
	 
Submitted by:
Judy C. Miner, Foothill College President
Additional contact names:
John Mummert, Skip Barnes
Is backup provided?
Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
The South Bay Regional Public Safety Consortium (SBRPSTC) was created in 1994 to provide high quality training in the most efficient manner possible to public safety professionals. The Consortium is comprised of Evergreen Valley College, Gavilan College, Hartnell College, Ohlone College, College of San Mateo, San Jose City College, Monterey Peninsula College, Foothill College, Lake Tahoe Community College and Mission College. The Foothill-De Anza Community College District signed the Joint Powers Agreement for the Consortium in 1998.
	 
Foothill was added to the Consortium in May 2012.
	 
The curriculum has been approved by the state through the collegeâs curriculum process, and students earn credit in Emergency Medical Technician or Fire Science classes.
	 
For the next fiscal year (2015-16) Foothill College estimates the contract instructional costs will amount to $535,748.00.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
By law, the seven-member Measure C Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee must include a student enrolled in one of the colleges in the district and active in a community college group, such as student government. Applicants are required to reside within the district's service area and may not be an employee, contractor, consultant or vendor. The student representative position on the Measure C Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee is currently vacant. Announcements of the vacancy were made to the colleges' student organizations and posted on the Measure C website. 
	 
The Chancellor recommends that the following candidate be appointed to a two-year term:
	 
Student Representative
Melissa Epps (New appointment)
Melissa Epps served as De Anza College's student trustee for 2014-2015 and has also served as a peer mentor for the Latino/a Empowerment at De Anza (LEAD), a general subject tutor for beginning levels of French with the De Anza College Tutoring Center, 2014-2015 President of the De Anza Rainbow Club, and as a volunteer for the Kirsch Center and the Adaptive Physical Education Center. She is currently working toward a certificate from the Institute of Community and Civic Engagement (ICCE).
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor
Additional contact names:
					 
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Chancellor Linda Thor recommends that the Board appoint Melissa Epps to a two-year term as student representative on the Measure C Citizens' Bond Oversight Committee.

A proposed revision to the district's mission statement (board policy 1200) is attached for first reading. The policy has been revised to incorporate language required by community college baccalaureate degree pilot program legislation and to ensure compliance with accreditation standards. Added language is indicated on the attachment by bold, underlined text, and deleted text is indicated by strikethrough. This is a technical revision only. A full review of the district's mission statement will take place in 2016 as part of the development of a new district strategic plan.
	 
The revised policy was approved by the Chancellor's Advisory Council on May 22, 2015, and will be presented for governing board approval at the July 13, 2015, meeting.

Accreditation Standard I.A.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
A proposed new board policy concerning institutional effectiveness is attached for first reading. The policy and a related new administrative procedure were developed in response to provisions of the Seymour-Campbell Student Success Act of 2012 that tie funding to the development of a goals framework that addresses accreditation status, fiscal viability, student performance and outcomes, and programmatic compliance with state and federal guidelines as well as the Senate Bill 876 requirement that the goals be challenging and quantifiable, address achievement gaps for underrepresented populations, and align the educational attainment of California's adult population to the workforce and economic needs of the state.
	 
The proposed policy was approved by the Academic and Professional Matters Committee and the Chancellor's Advisory Council on May 22, 2015, and will be presented for governing board approval on July 13, 2015.
	 
References:
Accreditation standards I.B.5-9
Education Code Sections 78210 et seq. and 84754.6
	 
Submitted by:
Linda Thor

Voting members of the Operating Engineers Local Union #3 (OE3) have ratified the tentative agreement on the topic of 2014-2015 compensation.  The Board is hereby requested to approve the 2014-2015 compensation settlement reached between the Foothill-De Anza Community College District and the Operating Engineers Local Union #3 Employees for 2014-2015.
	 
The 2014-2015 settlement regarding compensation and other economic matters includes the following:
               
Effective July 1, 2014
Salary adjustment of 2.50% (equivalent to the State-provided .085% COLA plus 1.65%) on the OE3 salary schedules, Appendix B.
Effective July 1, 2015
   The addition of Article 6.7 Specialty Assignment Pay as follows:
  6.7.1      A full time officer who has been assigned a specialty assignment shall be entitled to be the specialty assignment differentials of 5% of the officer’s base pay.  Specialty assignment areas include:
Motorcycle Unit
Bicycle Unit
Crime Scene Investigation
Field Training Officer
6.7.2      Assignments are made at the discretion of the Directory, District Safety and Security (Chief of Police).  The required P.O.S.T. Certified training for the related assignment must be completed before assignment commences. 
	 
Addition to Appendix A:
Police Officer Trainee Job Description
Addition of a Police Officer Trainee job description
Police Officer I/II Job Description
Revision of the Police Officer I job description to Police Officer I/II job description to include advancement to Police Officer II with Advanced P.O.S.T. certificate.  
Addition to Appendix B:
Police Officer Trainee -  Range 42
Police Officer II - Range 59
Specialty Assignment Pay – Additional 5% of the officer’s base pay.  Specialty assigned areas include:
Motorcycle Unit,
Bicycle Unit,
Crime Scene Investigation, or
Field Training Officer.

Background and Analysis:
	 
Voting members of the Teamsters Local 287 (Teamsters) have ratified the tentative agreement on the topic of 2014-2015 compensation.  The Board is hereby requested to approve the 2014-2015 compensation settlement reached between the Foothill-De Anza Community College District and the Teamsters Local 287.  
	 
The 2014-2015 settlement regarding compensation and other economic matters includes the following: 
               
Effective July 1, 2014
Salary adjustment of 2.5% (equivalent to the State-provided .85% COLA plus 1.65%) on the Teamsters salary schedule, Appendix C.
Effective July 1, 2015
Article 6.6 Professional Growth Award
Awards earned in the amount of $70 per month shall be increased to $90 per month
Effective July 1, 2015
Applies to awards earned between July 1, 2000 and June 30, 2015. 
Amount increases from $840 to $1080
Maximum number of awards, irrespective of amount, shall be 12 awards, including any awards earned while in non-Teamsters status but that have continued while in Teamsters status. 
Awards earned prior to July 1, 2000 will remain at the amount in effect as of June 30, 2015.
Maximum amount of PGA earnings, from all awards shall be $12,960
Earning PGA credits shall be adjusted to reflect a change in the amount of educational units to reflect fewer units in Category 1 for employees who have earned a Masterâs Degree or a Bachelorâs Degree or a lower degree with additional units per the attached. 
Hours for leadership and committee work are enhanced. 
Physical education credits are changed to activities to recognize non-credit activities that may qualify with limits.
The parties have also reached agreement regarding the following:
	 
Effective July 1, 2015
Article 7.1 Holidays
Clarify Current Practices regarding Holiday pay = 8 hours per holiday for full time employees; holidays paid at a prorated basis for less than full time. 
Article 7.2.3 Vacations (usage)
Vacation leave may be used in increments of not less than one hour. 
Temporary Hires
Terms and conditions applying to hiring of temporary employees and apply while waiting to complete a recruitment.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College Disability Support Programs & Services is requesting to purchase a medium duty bus with wheelchair access to transport students throughout campus and offsite functions. The District selected Ford/Gravel based on the information and specifications provided by the Disability Support Programs & Services staff.
	 
The State of California awarded competitive contracts to two bus sales companies: A-Z Bus Sales and Creative Bus Sales. Purchasing requested pricing from both companies per the information and specifications provided from the department. A-Z Bus Sales quoted $87,982.85 (plus applicable sales tax and fees) and Creative Bus Sales is $88,890.00 (plus applicable sales tax and fees).
	 
Because the estimate cost of the Ford/Graval Medium Duty Bus will exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts award by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”. The competitively bid California Contract with A-Z Bus Sales is available and includes the items required by the college.
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than offered on the California Contract for the same goods and services. The California Contract established discounts for Medium Duty Buses and 5 years/100,000 mile Limited Body Warranty.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services
Additional contact names:
Stacey Shears, John Pham
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue a purchase order to A-Z Bus Sales in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to the Public Contract Code 20652 and the California Contract # 7-12-23-15-04.
items.item_text: Authorize the use of the State of California Contract # 7-12-23-15-04 to purchase Ford/Graval Medium Duty Bus with Wheelchair Access from A-Z Bus Sales pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652
items.item_text_raw: 29) Authorize the use of the State of California Contract # 7-12-23-15-04 to purchase Ford/Graval Medium Duty Bus with Wheelchair Access from A-Z Bus Sales pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
New utilities must be constructed to serve the Education Center, which requires easements to be granted to utility owners to allow for installation, maintenance and future repair/removal of those utilities.
	 
Because of this the District wishes to grant easements to Pacific Gas and Electric Company for electrical and gas services.  According to Education Code Sections 81310 et seq., the following process must be followed for the granting of easements:
	 
1.      The Board of Trustees must adopt a resolution of notice of intention to grant the easements.  The resolution must be adopted by at least a 2/3 vote of board members and must be signed by at least 2/3 of the Board members.
	 
2.     Notice must be published in a local newspaper and posted in three public places.
	 
3.     A public hearing must be conducted.
	 
4.     The Board of Trustees must adopt a resolution authorizing the granting of the easements.
	 
The Boardâs adoption of this resolution completes item #1 of the process to grant the easements.  The public hearing and adoption of the resolution granting the easements will occur at the Boardâs next scheduled meeting.
	 
Submitted by:
Steve Kitchen, Executive Director, Facilities and Operations
Additional contact names:
Art Heinrich, Bond Program Director
Is backup provided?
Yes

Background and Analysis:
	 
This project is to remove and replace existing roofing materials including skylights at the ESA Eco Lab Classroom Building on the De Anza College Campus. 
	 
ATI Architects and Engineers prepared the construction documents and a complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 16 and April 23, 2015. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to seven (7) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  A mandatory bid walk was held on April 30, 2015, and a total of nine (9) contractors attended the walk.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 20, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Seven (7) contractors submitted bids and the bid results are summarized below:
	 
BID RESULTS
	 
Contractor
Total Bid Proposal Amount 
(includes $20,000 for Allowances 1 & 2)
Andy’s Roofing Company, Inc.
$56,574
Roofing Constructors, Inc. DBA:  Western Roofing Service
$75,000
Alcal Specialty Contracting, Inc. 
$82,216
Joseph Murphy Construction, Inc.
$88,730
ICC General Contractors, Inc.
$91,976
Swenson & Associates, Inc.
$106,000
Best Contracting Services, Inc.
$128,937
	 
	 
Purchasing Services staff has confirmed that Andy’s Roofing Company, Inc. has successfully completed similar projects for Contra Costa Community College, Santa Clara Unified School District, and Castro Valley Unified School District. 
	 
The base bid proposal amount of $56,574 submitted by Andy’s Roofing Company, Inc. is within the construction estimate of $75,000.
	 
This project will be paid for by 2014-15 Physical Plant Block Grant funds.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
On February 27, 2008, the board approved two five-year contracts with Ellucian, including a Software License & Services Agreement and a Start-up Support / Maintenance Services Agreement, both associated with the procurement of the Banner administrative information system. The contracts covered many components in addition to Banner software including license and maintenance agreements for other software applications that integrate with Banner, but are produced by different vendors. One software application was the Oracle database management system (Oracle DBMS), which is produced and licensed by the Oracle Corporation.
	 
In order to safeguard the critical Oracle database infrastructure, the District is looking into the additional licensing of data encryption technology from Oracle and Ellucian. This technology is tightly integrated at the database level, and can only be licensed from the Oracle Corporation through Ellucian services. When implemented, the technology will encrypt all the data elements at rest. In case a data breach occurs, the data cannot be read without a special encryption key.
	 
To encrypt the Oracle database, the District needs to license additional software from Oracle and implementation services from Ellucian. The cost to implement this project is summarized at the table below:
	 
					 
One time
Recurring
Software license cost
$173,478
					 
Implementation
$ 45,236
					 
Maintenance /Year
					 
$ 38,165*
3 Years total
$218,714
$120,314*
Grand Total: $339,028
·       * The cost of the maintenance agreement increases by 5% a year but is also adjusted periodically for the size of the institution based on FTES.
	 
Submitted by:
Joe Moreau, Vice Chancellor of Technology
Additional contact names:
Chien Shih

Yes

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
This project will require the contractor to drill a 10” diameter borehole x approximately 300’deep water well for the purpose of locating underground water sources on the Foothill College campus to tie into existing irrigation.  The scope of work also requires minor electrical work to install a submersible pump and minor concrete work to prepare and pour a concrete pad for the well and electrical connections.
	 
The bid was legally advertised to contractors on April 10 and April 17, 2014. The “Invitation to Bid” was also sent to nine (9) builder’s exchanges and advertised in the San Jose Post Record as well as posted on “BidNet” at www.govbids.com.  Bids were publicly opened and read on May 14, 2015 in the Purchasing Services office. Only one (1) contractor submitted a bid, Calstate Construction, Inc., at a price of $149,500 for the Base Bid Proposal Amount.
	 
Calstate Construction, Inc. has confirmed that its bid amount of $149,500 is true and accurate for the work as specified and it will subcontract the well drilling to one of the premier well drillers in the Bay Area.  Calstate previously completed the DOB Swing Space project at Foothill College and also the G Building Renovation project at De Anza College. It is currently under contract for the Kiosks at De Anza College.
	 
Measure C scheduled maintenance and 2014-15 Physical Plant Block Grant money will fund the project. 
	 
Submitted by:
  Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services - 6166
Additional contact names:
  Steve Kitchen - 6150, Art Heinrich - 6295, Jennifer Mahato - 6178, Gina Bailey - 6165
Is backup provided?
  No

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
Phase 1 of the Campus Drive project consists of all work associated with Parking Lot E and walkway adjacent to the Campus Drive roadway as indicated in the documents. The scope of work includes complete parking lot renovation including: stripping the existing site; re-grading and modifying the entries from Campus Drive into the lot and realignment of the drive aisles; preparation for new parking lot paving; installing new curbs, gutters, sidewalks, stairs, curb ramps and re-paving the parking lot; installing new landscaping, lighting, emergency phones and providing power to relocated ticket machines; providing directional and way-finding signage; and all associated erosion and dust control measures throughout the course of the work.  BKF Engineers prepared the construction documents.  A complete set of all bid documents are on file in the Purchasing Services Department.
	 
In accordance with Public Contract Code Section 20651.5, a community college district may prequalify bidders as part of a sealed bid process, and only prequalified bidders are allowed to submit a bid.  
	 
On March 4 and March 11, 2015, Purchasing Services advertised the Prequalification/Bid Document 1721R-248 in the San Jose Post Record, sent it to seven (7) builder’s exchanges, and posted it on Bidnet.  Eleven (11) general contractors submitted completed prequalification questionnaires to the District by the March 30, 2015 deadline, and all of them attended the mandatory pre-bid job walk.  Only general contractors who attended the mandatory bid walk and were later deemed to be prequalified were permitted to submit a bid.
	 
Purchasing Services staff and the De Anza College Measure C Bond Projects Director evaluated the prequalification questionnaires based upon the following key evaluation factors: license information, litigation history, construction experience, safety history, bonding capacity, insurance capacity, and financial capacity.  They determined that six (6) General Contractors (see list below) met the minimum requirements of the prequalification questionnaire and received point scores above 80% of the total points available.

Doug Ross, Inc. DBA: Central Valley Asphalt (CVA) is the lowest responsive and responsible bidder. CVA has completed projects for the College of the Sequoias and Clovis Unified School District. 
	 
The bid price of $1,830,056 submitted by CVA is over the engineer’s estimate of $1,700,000 - however, it is within the overall project budget of $2,612,248.   The project’s construction contingency will be supplemented with a future budget transfer if required.  The project will be funded through Measure C.

items.item_details:
Background and Analysis:
	 
De Anza College needs to purchase furniture for the library that is currently under construction. Because the estimated cost of the furniture may exceed the current statutory bid threshold of $86,000, the District must either conduct its own bidding and award process or obtain board authorization to utilize existing contracts awarded by other public entities. This process is commonly known as “piggybacking”.  The competitively bid National Cooperative Purchasing Alliance (NCPA) contract with Demco Inc. is available and it includes the items that are required by De Anza College.  The NCPA contract was a competitive solicitation and it was awarded through Region 14 (a local government agency in the State of Texas) on behalf of itself and all states, local governments, school districts, and higher education institutions, and other government agencies. District staff, and legal counsel have reviewed and approve of using the NCPA contract. 
	 
It is highly unlikely that a separate bid process conducted by our District would result in more favorable prices, terms, and conditions than the prices offered on the NCPA contract for the same goods and services. The NCPA contract awarded to Demco Inc. establishes discounts for various furniture lines and is inclusive of project management services, field measurements and design services, along with tailgate delivery 
	 
The furniture will be purchased using Measure C funds.
	 
Submitted by:
Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services x6166
Additional contact names:
Donna Jones Dulin, Lorrie Ranck, Annette Perez
Is backup provided?
No
items.item_recommendation: Pam Grey, Director of Purchasing Services, recommends the Board of Trustees make a finding that it is in the best interest of the District to issue purchase orders for furniture and related services in excess of the legally mandated bid threshold pursuant to Public Contract Code 20652 and the NCPA contract #07-02.

Note that DA BT#42 dated 4/7/2014 that showed $2,000,000 transferred from Project 201, A8 to Project 216, Library, did not identify the separate funding sources of the transferred amount. Measure C portion of transferred amount was $1,211,875.19; Interest Earned portion was $788,124.81.
